hawaiian_text: I ia wā, noke aku ana ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ka  huhuki ā pau kekahi māla ‘uala ā luna o kekahi  māla ‘uala, pēlā nō ka huhuki ‘ana ā pau nā māla  ‘elua ā kū ke āhua o ka lau o ka ‘uala, he kanahā  āhua ka nui o nā māla ‘elua. A laila, ho‘i a‘ela ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o a hō‘ā i ke ahi a ‘ōhinu akula ‘ehā  ‘au o ka ‘uala i luna o kapuahi e ‘ā ana. Iā ia e  ‘ōhinu ana i luna o ke ahi, ho‘i maila kona makua  kāne kōlea ā hiki, nīnau akula i kona makuahine, iā  Pōka‘ī: “‘A‘ole.” ‘Ī aku ‘o Puali‘i: “‘Ae, ‘o ke po‘o  ona a me nā maka ka mea e ‘īna‘i ai ku‘u ‘uala i  kēia lā, no laila, eia kona lā e make ai ia‘u.”
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_translation: Then, again, Nāmakaokapāo‘o covered all over a certain salt field, and on top of another salt field, just as the covering of the two salt fields, the shape of the leaves of salt, is a great form. Then, again, Nāmakaokapāo‘o covered the fire, a more intense fire, eight pieces of salt on top of a place where it is placed. For that, the fire is covered on top of the fire, then the man's head is placed below, and the woman's head is placed. To Pōka‘ī: "No." Puali‘i says: "Yes, the great one is the one who and the eyes of the thing that is eaten in this day, then, in that day, he is made."
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_commentary:
• [Allegorical interpretation of the passage]  
  – The text uses salt and fire as symbolic elements to represent the tension between sacred preservation and transformation. Salt fields ("māla ‘uala") may allegorically signify the sacred resources of the land, while the act of covering ("huhuki") reflects rituals of concealment or protection, possibly tied to the 'Ai Kapu (sacred food laws) of pre-contact Hawaii.  
  – The "fire" ("ahi") and "eight pieces of salt" ("‘ehā ‘au o ka ‘uala") could symbolize the balance between spiritual and material forces, with eight representing the cyclical nature of time or the eight directions in Hawaiian cosmology.  

• [Analysis of character names and symbolism]  
  – **Nāmakaokapāo‘o**: "Nā" (the), "Maka" (eyes), "o" (of), "ka pāo‘o" (parrotfish). The name translates to "The Eyes of the Parrotfish," symbolizing vigilance or guardianship over sacred resources. Parrotfish ("pāo‘o") are culturally significant as symbols of the ocean’s vitality and are linked to the god Kanaloa, associated with the deep sea.  
  – **Pōka‘ī** and **Puali‘i**: "Pō" (night/darkness), "kā‘ī" (to cover/hide), "pau" (end). These names may reflect duality—Pōka‘ī ("Night Hider") and Puali‘i ("End of the Hiding")—symbolizing the conflict between secrecy (traditional practices) and revelation (post-contact changes).  

• [Historical and cultural context]  
  – **'Ai Kapu era (pre-1819)**: The act of covering salt fields may allude to the sacredness of salt in Hawaiian society, used in rituals and as a preservative. The 'Ai Kapu system, which governed food taboos, would have required such symbolic acts to maintain spiritual order.  
  – **Post-1820 missionary influence**: The mention of "eight pieces of salt" could subtly critique the disruption of traditional practices, as missionaries later introduced new systems of resource management, altering sacred rituals.  
  – **Numerical symbolism**: The number "eight" (‘ehā) may reference the *kāne-mālikai* (eight directions) or the *mo‘olelo* (mythological cycles), emphasizing the interconnectedness of spiritual and temporal realms.  

• [Social commentary and critique]  
  – The dialogue between Pōka‘ī and Puali‘i ("No" vs. "Yes") reflects the tension between preserving ancestral knowledge and adopting new ideologies post-contact. Pōka‘ī’s "No" could symbolize resistance to change, while Puali‘i’s "Yes" represents adaptation.  
  – The placement of "man’s head" and "woman’s head" beneath the fire may allegorically depict the subjugation of traditional gender roles under colonial or missionary influence, where indigenous practices were marginalized.  
  – The phrase "eia kona lā e make ai ia‘u" ("in that day, he is made") hints at the erasure of indigenous systems, as the 'Ai Kapu were abolished in 1819, leading to the collapse of sacred food laws and the rise of Western practices.
raw_response:
<translation>  
Then, again, Nāmakaokapāo‘o covered all over a certain salt field, and on top of another salt field, just as the covering of the two salt fields, the shape of the leaves of salt, is a great form. Then, again, Nāmakaokapāo‘o covered the fire, a more intense fire, eight pieces of salt on top of a place where it is placed. For that, the fire is covered on top of the fire, then the man's head is placed below, and the woman's head is placed. To Pōka‘ī: "No." Puali‘i says: "Yes, the great one is the one who and the eyes of the thing that is eaten in this day, then, in that day, he is made."  
</translation>  

<commentary>  
• [Allegorical interpretation of the passage]  
  – The text uses salt and fire as symbolic elements to represent the tension between sacred preservation and transformation. Salt fields ("māla ‘uala") may allegorically signify the sacred resources of the land, while the act of covering ("huhuki") reflects rituals of concealment or protection, possibly tied to the 'Ai Kapu (sacred food laws) of pre-contact Hawaii.  
  – The "fire" ("ahi") and "eight pieces of salt" ("‘ehā ‘au o ka ‘uala") could symbolize the balance between spiritual and material forces, with eight representing the cyclical nature of time or the eight directions in Hawaiian cosmology.  

• [Analysis of character names and symbolism]  
  – **Nāmakaokapāo‘o**: "Nā" (the), "Maka" (eyes), "o" (of), "ka pāo‘o" (parrotfish). The name translates to "The Eyes of the Parrotfish," symbolizing vigilance or guardianship over sacred resources. Parrotfish ("pāo‘o") are culturally significant as symbols of the ocean’s vitality and are linked to the god Kanaloa, associated with the deep sea.  
  – **Pōka‘ī** and **Puali‘i**: "Pō" (night/darkness), "kā‘ī" (to cover/hide), "pau" (end). These names may reflect duality—Pōka‘ī ("Night Hider") and Puali‘i ("End of the Hiding")—symbolizing the conflict between secrecy (traditional practices) and revelation (post-contact changes).  

• [Historical and cultural context]  
  – **'Ai Kapu era (pre-1819)**: The act of covering salt fields may allude to the sacredness of salt in Hawaiian society, used in rituals and as a preservative. The 'Ai Kapu system, which governed food taboos, would have required such symbolic acts to maintain spiritual order.  
  – **Post-1820 missionary influence**: The mention of "eight pieces of salt" could subtly critique the disruption of traditional practices, as missionaries later introduced new systems of resource management, altering sacred rituals.  
  – **Numerical symbolism**: The number "eight" (‘ehā) may reference the *kāne-mālikai* (eight directions) or the *mo‘olelo* (mythological cycles), emphasizing the interconnectedness of spiritual and temporal realms.  

• [Social commentary and critique]  
  – The dialogue between Pōka‘ī and Puali‘i ("No" vs. "Yes") reflects the tension between preserving ancestral knowledge and adopting new ideologies post-contact. Pōka‘ī’s "No" could symbolize resistance to change, while Puali‘i’s "Yes" represents adaptation.  
  – The placement of "man’s head" and "woman’s head" beneath the fire may allegorically depict the subjugation of traditional gender roles under colonial or missionary influence, where indigenous practices were marginalized.  
  – The phrase "eia kona lā e make ai ia‘u" ("in that day, he is made") hints at the erasure of indigenous systems, as the 'Ai Kapu were abolished in 1819, leading to the collapse of sacred food laws and the rise of Western practices.  
</commentary>
reference_translation: At that time, Nāmakaokapāo‘o was busy tearing  apart the sweet potato patches, yanking them out.  He tore apart both sweet potato patches until  there rose a mound of sweet potato leaves, forty  mounds in all from the two patches. Then  Nāmakaokapāo‘o went back and lit a fire to broil  four sweet potato vines on a fire pit. As he was  broiling the vines, wilting them, his stepfather  came back and reached him and asked   Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s mother, Pōka‘ī, and she said,  “No.” Puali‘i said, “Yes, his head and eyes as food  to go with the sweet potatoes that I’ll eat today.  So, today I will kill him.”
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 6:**• The numbers referred to in this paragraph are  interesting and likely a riddle to solve, with esoteric  meaning: 2, 4, 40\. Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o is a child, but  behaves like a mature adult, albeit destructive and  spiteful, but calculating. This has allegorical meaning  and likely relates to wastefulness and the need to  dismantle ‘Ai Kapu practices.  • Pua-li‘i was so enraged by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s  destruction of the sweet potato patches that he  threatened to eat his head (po‘o) and eyes (nā maka)  with sweet potato in place of ulua fish. The head of  the ulua or of a person likely represents the sweet  potato tuber and the eyes likely represent the sweet  potato vine cutting (maka) that is used to replant and  perpetuate the crop, symbolically, the people of the  land. This also explains the meaning of ʻmaka’ in the  name, Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o, with ʻpāo‘o’ being used  as a poetic reference to ʻpo‘o’ (head).  – Ulua was used as a substitute for human sacrifice  on the heiau in the ‘Ai Kapu culture (footnote: Pukui & Elbert (1986:369) *ulua*: “This fish was substituted for human sacrifices when the latter were not available , probably because of word magic and the meaning of *ulua 2* \[to grow/increase; to be possessed by a god\]. Since an *ulua* replaces a man, *ulua* also means “man, sweetheart,” especially in love songs.”). In this case,  Pua-li‘i threatens to eat the human head and eyes  of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o in place of the ulua: the  opposite of normal ‘Ai Kapu custom. This appears  to allude to Pua-li‘i’s holding on to the ‘Ai Kapu  customs, going back in time allegorically, rather  than forward in time, where humans are no longer  sacrificed in the Western culture. Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o, on the other hand, represents going forward in time, a time of progressive thinking and   abandonment of the ‘Ai Kapu;
